description:
At ABCD HEAD START, we prepare your child for preschool and kindergarten using activities and experiences that develop their cognitive and emotional skills. We also have programs for pregnant women and children to fit the needs of your family.


Head Start is a family development program that offers comprehensive services for your child as well as your entire family. Part of a highly successful national program, ABCD Head Start has locations throughout Boston, Everett, Malden, and Medford. Our services concentrate on your child’s education, nutrition, and physical and mental health.
name: ABCD Head Start & Early Head Start - 80 Lexington Street
pointOfContact: ABCD Head Start & Children’s Services Central Office

description:
Maybe you’re a teen parent or you’re struggling with homelessness, or your family is experiencing other difficult circumstances. Our Head Start and Early Head Start specialized services can provide superb childcare and early education while you work, look for a job, or pursue your education. 


 If you are a parent experiencing homelessness, you may qualify forspecialized services. You’ll need a referral from the MassachusettsDepartment of Housing and Community Development (DHCD). If your family is Department of Children and Families (DCF)-involved, you may also qualify for a specialized DCF Supportive placement. Specialized child care openings are available at most Early Head Start and Head Start program locations.
howToApply: Call the East Boston ABCD office using the button above or manually enter 617.567.8855. Let the office know about your situation and they will be able to assist you. You can also contact the office via email using the above button or by emailing headstart@bostonabcd.org.
name: ABCD Specialized Childcare - 130 Condor Street
pointOfContact: East Boston Head Start & Children's Services - Condor Street

description:
Transitional Aid to Families with Dependent Children (TAFDC) is an economic assistance (cash benefit) program that helps pregnant individuals, families and caregivers explore opportunities, improve their finances, and reach their goals.  



When you receive TAFDC you may be eligible for:

 * Two cash payments per month to meet your basic needs,
 * Enrollment into MassHealth coverage,
 * Referral to free employment and training programs,
 * Referral for free child care while you work on your education and employment goals,
 * Money for transportation to get to school, training, work, or to look for a job,
 * One-time payment of $300 for infants under 6 months, and
 * Clothing allowance: one-time payment of $400 for each eligible children in early Fall.
howToApply:
There are three ways to apply: 
 1. Online using [this link](https://dtaconnect.eohhs.mass.gov/applyTafdc) 
 2. Over the phone at 6175511700 
 3. In-person at the DTA Chelsea Center Transitional Assistance Office, located at 80 Everett Avenue, Chelsea, MA 02150. 


  If you are not sure if your family can get TAFDC benefits, apply. DTA will interview you and decide if you are eligible under the TAFDC rules.
name: TAFDC - DTA Chelsea Center
pointOfContact: DTA Chelsea Center Transitional Assistance Office

description:
Emergency Aid to the Elderly Disabled and Children (EAEDC) is a 100% state-funded program providing cash and medical assistance to certain categories of needy persons residing in Massachusetts. These categories are: Elderly, Disabled, Caring for a disabled person, caretaker family and participating in Massachusetts Rehabilitation Commission. 
 Individuals in the following categories are eligible: 
 * Aged 65 or older and applying for SSI 
 * Persons receiving treatment from substance abuse halfway houses 
 * Physically or mentally disabled 
 * Caring for disabled individuals who would otherwise be institutionalized.
howToApply: Apply over the phone by calling the DTA Chelsea Center at (617)-551-1700, or online at [this link](https://dtaconnect.eohhs.mass.gov/applyEaedc)
name: EAEDC - DTA Chelsea Center
pointOfContact: DTA Chelsea Center Transitional Assistance Office

description:
MassHealth provides health benefits and help paying for them to qualifying children, families, seniors, and people with disabilities living in Massachusetts. We may offer benefits directly or help pay for all or part of your health insurance premiums. If you are a member, you may have access to doctor visits, dental, prescription drugs, behavioral health services, and other important health care services. 


 If you want to know more about which MassHealth programs you qualify for, you can take [MassHealth's own quiz here](https://www.mahix.org/individual/).
howToApply:
1. Online - If you are under 65, an [MA Login Account](https://www.mass.gov/ma-login-accounts-for-health-coverage) is the fastest way to renew your coverage. 
 If you don’t have an account, use the web link provided in your renewal notice to create an account. You can also call the MassHealth Customer Service Center to get help creating your online account. You’ll need an email address. Need help? [MA Login Accounts for Current Members](https://www.mass.gov/info-details/ma-login-accounts-for-current-members). 
 2. By mail - First, fill out and sign the [Massachusetts Application for Health and Dental Coverage and Help Paying Costs](https://www.mass.gov/doc/massachusetts-application-for-health-and-dental-coverage-and-help-paying-costs-0/download). Afterwards, mail it to: Health Insurance Processing Center, PO Box 4405, Taunton, MA 02780 
 3. By phone - Call the MassHealth Customer Service Center at (800) 841-2900 during regular ohurs (Monday through Friday 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.) 


 You can find more information on applying [here](https://www.mass.gov/how-to/apply-for-masshealth-the-health-safety-net-or-the-childrens-medical-security-plan).
name: MassHealth

description:
Helping MassHealth children with behavioral, emotional, and mental health needs and their families with integrated behavioral health services and a comprehensive, community-based system of care. 
 CBHI partners with child and family serving state agencies, providers, and payers to ensure that services meet the individual needs of the child and family, are easy for families to find and access, and make families feel welcomed and respected. 


 Some kinds of services provided by CBHI include: 
 1. Home and Community Based Services, such as Outpatient Therapy, In-Home Therapy, and Intensive Care Coordination, 
 2. Autism Services, such as Applied Behavior Analysis (APA), and 
 3. Youth Substance-use Services, such as the Intensive Outpatient Program (IOP) and Youth Stabilization Services (YSS)
howToApply: The application process depends on which CBHI program you're applying to. You can find CBHI providers at [this link](https://www.mass.gov/service-details/find-a-cbhi-provider).
name: Children's Behavioral Health Initiative (CBHI) for Families

description:
Good health is an important step towards successful resettlement. RHPP can help you obtain affordable health care – including health insurance – and provide you with information and referral to health services. 
 Services include: 
 * Healthcare education addressing: 
      * the Massachusetts medical system
      * immunizations
      * selecting a primary care physician
      * current public health concerns
      * mental health
      * home care and safety
 * Case management services for physical and mental health: 
    * translation and interpretation services
    * follow-up on conditions identified in the Refugee Health Assessment
    * referral to mainstream health care services
    * on-going support through home visits and phone call
    * access to health insurance plans and translations
howToApply:
Contact the Office for Refugees and Immigrants (ORI) to be connected with the right services for you. You can do so by: 
 * Heading to the ORI main office, located at 600 Washington Street, 4th floor, Boston, MA 02111, or 
 * by calling their number at (617) 727-7888
name: Refugee Health Promotion Program (RHPP)

description:
Founded in 1969, Pine Street Inn provides a comprehensive range of services to 1400 homeless men and women each day. We are the largest homeless services provider in New England, and could not do this important work without the support of our donors and local community.
  Since that time we have been providing a comprehensive range of programs and services, including housing, emergency services, and workforce development. Our ultimate goal is to end homelessness by making permanent housing a reality for all. 
 Pine Street's four shelters, totaling 410 beds, provide guests with a safe place to lay their head at night as well as nutritious meals, laundry services and showers. We also offer access to health clinics through a partnership with Boston Health Care for the Homeless. 
 These shelters are: the Men's Inn, the Women's In, the Shattuck Shelter, and the Holy Family Shelter. A fifth, temporary shelter, the Charles River Inn, was opened recently to accomodate guests during the pandemic.
howToApply: If you are new to emergency shelter, or are returning after some time away, you will meet with a member of Pine Street’s Triage team to assess what can be done to immediately or very quickly resolve your need for shelter. You can contact the Triage team at 617.892.9228
name: Pine Street Inn Emergency Shelters
pointOfContact: Pine Street Inn - General Information (Not Triage Team)
